content:
EXISTING STRUCTURES
────────────────────────
### Stone Furnace Facility at (0.0, 0.0)
Consists of:
– Stone Furnace at (0.0, 0.0)  
– Iron Chest at (1.5, 0.5)  
Use-case: Primary smelting station for converting raw materials into iron plates.

### Iron Ore Mining Setup at (–16.0, –51.0)
Consists of:
– Burner Mining Drill at (–16.0, –51.0)  
– Burner Inserter at (–14.5, –49.5)  
– Iron Chest at (–13.5, –49.5)  
– Burner Inserter at (–14.5, –47.5)  
– Fast Inserter at (–12.5, –49.5)  
– Fast Inserter at (–13.5, –45.5)  
Use-case: Extraction and initial transport of iron ore for further processing.

### Copper Furnace at (–27.0, –60.0)
Consists of:
– Furnace at (–27.0, –60.0)  
Use-case: Processes copper ore into copper plates for advanced manufacturing.

### Lab Power Integration System at (0.5, 2.5)
Consists of:
– Lab at (0.5, 2.5)  
– Offshore Pump at (–7.5, 25.5)  
– Offshore Pump at (–9.5, 24.5)  
– Boiler at (2.0, 17.5) (sufficient fuel though water supply from the Offshore Pump remains unestablished)  
– Steam Engine at (11.5, 27.5) (currently producing no power)  
Use-case: Supports lab operations through integrated power and fluid systems; persistent connectivity challenges continue despite adequate boiler fuel.

### Copper Cable Factory at (2.5, 6.5)
Consists of:
– Repositioned Assembling Machine at (2.5, 6.5) configured for the Copper Cable recipe (status: NO_POWER)  
– Pre-existing Small Electric Pole at (4.5, 6.5) serving as a local power node  
– Stone Furnace at (7.0, 11.0) for smelting Copper Ore into Copper Plates  
– Additional Small Electric Pole at (2.5, 3.5) placed using direction UP (spacing 1)  
– Additional Small Electric Pole at (2.5, 8.5) placed using direction DOWN (spacing 0)  
– Intermediate Small Electric Pole at (8.5, 18.5) manually placed to bridge the connection between the Steam Engine and the Assembling Machine  
– Fallback Small Electric Pole at (0.5, 6.5) placed adjacent to the Assembling Machine to help bridge the power gap  
– Steam Engine at (11.5, 27.5) connected via multiple chain attempts including a direct link to the intermediate pole (currently producing no power)  
Use-case: Produces Copper Cables from smelted Copper Plates; persistent power network issues remain despite multiple connection enhancements.

### Fluid Pipelines (Multiple Pipe Groups)
Consists of:
– Multiple PipeGroups spanning positions such as (–10.5, 22.5) to (–9.5, 23.5); additional groups at (8.5, 5.5), (10.5, 4.5), (–9.5, 24.5) (to the Boiler), (2.5, 9.5), (10.5, 9.5), (1.5, 11.5), (–1.5, 17.5), (0.5, 17.5), (6.5, 16.5), (–1.5, 21.5) and (4.5, 25.5)  
Use-case: Transports fluids between production components; connectivity challenges persist between the Boiler and the Steam Engine.

### Integrated Components
Consists of:
– BeltGroup connecting inserter and belt outputs  
– Electricity network via multiple ElectricityGroups with poles at positions such as [(-10.5, -49.5), (-12.5, -48.5), (-12.5, -50.5)], near (3.5, 0.5), [(6.5, 3.5), (5.5, 8.5)] and [(2.5, 30.5), (7.5, 26.5)]  
Use-case: Provides overall material handling and supports factory operations with an extensive power network.

ERROR TIPS
────────────────────────
• Crafting Ingredient Shortages  
 – When crafting Small Electric Poles, errors may occur due to missing sub-ingredients such as copper-cable or wood. Ensure all required components are available before initiating a craft.

• Entity Placement and Collision Issues  
 – Placement failures can occur when attempting to place Small Electric Poles in occupied zones, as seen by the collision at (4.5, 6.5) near the Assembling Machine. Verify that target tiles are clear and adjust spacing or direction accordingly.

• Power Network Connection Errors  
 – Insufficient Small Electric Pole inventory has led to failures in connecting the Assembling Machine to the intermediate pole. Verify that the inventory meets the connection requirements before establishing power chains.  
 – Multiple chain connection attempts—including direct links from the Steam Engine to the intermediate network—have failed, with the Steam Engine producing no power. Confirm that the Steam Engine is receiving adequate fuel and fluid to generate energy.  
 – The persistent NO_POWER status of the Assembling Machine suggests the overall network lacks continuity; re-evaluate pole placements and chain connectivity.

• Function and Type Usage Errors  
 – A NameError (e.g., 'local_pole' is not defined) occurred due to improper variable initialization. Ensure that all variables are correctly defined and referenced.  
 – Avoid invoking object properties as functions (such as misusing Position.center) to prevent type-related errors.

• Fluid Connection Failures  
 – Failed attempts to connect the Offshore Pump to the Boiler indicate that connection points may be blocked or misaligned. Verify that both source and target connection points are unobstructed and properly configured for fluid transfer.

• Offshore Pump and Electronic Component Crafting Failures  
 – Ensure that all sub-ingredients and raw resources are available when crafting Offshore Pumps and other electronic components to avoid crafting interruptions.

• Repositioning and Buildable Area Computation Errors  
 – Inaccuracies in calculating buildable areas can lead to out-of-range placement or collision errors. Confirm that computed areas fall within allowable distances before placing entities.

• Resource Insertion and Availability Issues  
 – Verify that required entities are present in the inventory prior to placement; replenish stocks as needed to maintain continuous operations.

• Fuel and Resource Insertion Issues  
 – Maintain close monitoring of critical inputs such as boiler fuel and raw materials. Replenish these resources promptly to support production and power generation.

• Component Extraction Failures  
 – Before attempting extraction operations, ensure that production cycles are complete and that valid outputs are available to prevent extraction errors.

• Removal Operation and Relocation Computation Errors  
 – Confirm entity existence and proper data type handling during removal or position computation operations to avoid type-related failures.
